## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 327, 355, 343]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1 (P1)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 370, 418, 385]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 392, 459, 407]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 390, 434]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 448, 785, 463]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 464, 320, 477]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 479, 504, 493]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 494, 504, 508]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 509, 380, 523]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 538, 907, 567]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 568, 907, 597]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 598, 600, 612]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 613, 606, 627]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 642, 608, 657]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 658, 755, 673]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 674, 440, 688]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 96, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Find the coefficient of \(\frac{1}{x^3}\) in the expansion of \(\left(x - \frac{2}{x}\right)^7\). [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 112, 920, 922]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 918, 108]]<|/det|>
The function f is defined by \(\operatorname {f}(x) = x^{3} + 2x^{2} - 4x + 7\) for \(x \geqslant -2\). Determine, showing all necessary working, whether f is an increasing function, a decreasing function or neither. [4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 123, 920, 923]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 75, 95, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 85, 616, 248]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 266, 918, 300]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows an arc \(BC\) of a circle with centre \(A\) and radius \(5\mathrm{cm}\). The length of the arc \(BC\) is \(4\mathrm{cm}\). The point \(D\) is such that the line \(BD\) is perpendicular to \(BA\) and \(DC\) is parallel to \(BA\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 314, 156, 332]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 314, 378, 332]]<|/det|>
Find angle \(BAC\) in radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 314, 920, 332]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 524, 153, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 524, 484, 542]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region \(BDC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 524, 920, 542]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 75, 918, 108]]<|/det|>
Two points \(A\) and \(B\) have coordinates \((-1, 1)\) and \((3, 4)\) respectively. The line \(BC\) is perpendicular to \(AB\) and intersects the \(x\)-axis at \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 122, 154, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 121, 567, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of \(BC\) and the \(x\)-coordinate of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 153, 920, 636]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 658, 154, 676]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 658, 712, 676]]<|/det|>
Find the distance \(AC\), giving your answer correct to 3 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 658, 920, 676]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 691, 920, 905]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
In an arithmetic progression the first term is \(a\) and the common difference is 3. The \(n\)th term is 94 and the sum of the first \(n\) terms is 1420. Find \(n\) and \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 85, 732, 343]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 361, 918, 444]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a solid figure \(OABCDEFG\) with a horizontal rectangular base \(OABC\) in which \(OA = 8\) units and \(AB = 6\) units. The rectangle \(DEFG\) lies in a horizontal plane and is such that \(D\) is 7 units vertically above \(O\) and \(DE\) is parallel to \(OA\). The sides \(DE\) and \(DG\) have lengths 4 units and 2 units respectively. Unit vectors \(\mathbf{i}, \mathbf{j}\) and \(\mathbf{k}\) are parallel to \(OA\), \(OC\) and \(OD\) respectively. Use a scalar product to find angle \(OBF\), giving your answer in the form \(\cos^{-1}\left(\frac{a}{b}\right)\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 446, 918, 464]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 75, 154, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 74, 620, 92]]<|/det|>
Hence, showing all necessary working, solve the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[397, 100, 602, 131]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\tan\theta + 1}{1 + \cos\theta} +\frac{\tan\theta - 1}{1 - \cos\theta} = 0\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 138, 295, 155]]<|/det|>
for \(0^{\circ} < \theta < 90^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 138, 918, 155]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 170, 918, 920]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
A curve passes through (0, 11) and has an equation for which \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = ax^2 + bx - 4\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 129, 156, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 128, 557, 147]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the curve in terms of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 128, 918, 147]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 161, 920, 905]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 75, 154, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 75, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
It is now given that the curve has a stationary point at (2, 3). Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\). [5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 920, 920]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 880, 92]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = 2x^{2} - 3x + 1\) and a line has equation \(y = kx + k^{2}\), where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 106, 156, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 106, 618, 123]]<|/det|>
Show that, for all values of \(k\), the curve and the line meet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 106, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 138, 920, 915]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 75, 154, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 75, 918, 108]]<|/det|>
State the value of \(k\) for which the line is a tangent to the curve and find the coordinates of the point where the line touches the curve. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 75, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[314, 87, 718, 313]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 332, 918, 370]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = 2(3x - 1)^{-\frac{1}{3}}\) and the lines \(x = \frac{2}{3}\) and \(x = 3\). The curve and the line \(x = \frac{2}{3}\) intersect at the point \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 384, 154, 402]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 384, 918, 418]]<|/det|>
Find, showing all necessary working, the volume obtained when the shaded region is rotated through \(360^{\circ}\) about the \(x\)-axis. [5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 918, 912]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 75, 154, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 75, 897, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the normal to the curve at \(A\), giving your answer in the form \(y = mx + c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 91, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 123, 920, 925]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 102, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 75, 156, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 75, 799, 93]]<|/det|>
Express \(2x^{2} - 12x + 11\) in the form \(a(x + b)^{2} + c\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are constants. [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 920, 458]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 483, 594, 501]]<|/det|>
<pre>The function f is defined by \(\operatorname {f}(x) = 2x^{2} - 12x + 11\) for \(x\leqslant k.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 514, 154, 532]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 514, 737, 532]]<|/det|>
State the largest value of the constant \(k\) for which f is a one-one function. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 660, 153, 677]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 660, 762, 677]]<|/det|>
For this value of \(k\) find an expression for \(\mathsf{f}^{-1}(\mathsf{x})\) and state the domain of \(\mathsf{f}^{-1}\). [4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 691, 920, 905]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 343, 524, 359]]<|/det|>
<pre>The function g is defined by \(\mathrm{g}(x) = x + 3\) for \(x \leqslant p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 371, 154, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 371, 918, 418]]<|/det|>
With \(k\) now taking the value 1, find the largest value of the constant \(p\) which allows the composite function fg to be formed, and find an expression for \(\mathrm{fg}(x)\) whenever this composite function exists.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 402, 918, 420]]<|/det|>
